* The z-statistic is theoretically acceptable here, but use of the t-statistic is more conservative.
All of the preceding analysis depends on the sample we draw from the population
being random. If the sample isn’t random, the central limit theorem doesn't apply, our
estimates won't have the desirable properties, and we can't form unbiased confidence
intervals. Surprisingly, creating a random sample is not as easy as one might believe.
There are a number of potential mistakes in sampling methods that can bias the results.
